title: 107_hr3922
content: The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" prevents corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code. Domestic now means created or organized in the United States or under U.S. law, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. Certain corporations are treated as domestic for tax purposes. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code. Certain corporations are treated as domestic for tax purposes in corporate expatriation transactions. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code to address corporate expatriation transactions where a nominally foreign acquiring corporation acquires substantially all properties of a domestic corporation. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic corporations for tax purposes, requiring that after a transaction, more than 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In certain cases, a lower stock ownership requirement of 50% may apply. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" amends the definition of domestic corporations for tax purposes, requiring that after a transaction, more than 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In certain cases, a lower stock ownership requirement of 50% may apply if the corporation lacks substantial business activities in the foreign country. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' includes any transaction where the corporation is created or organized in a foreign country and its stock is publicly traded in the US. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' includes any transaction where a nominally foreign acquiring corporation acquires properties of a domestic partnership. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' involves a foreign acquiring corporation obtaining properties of a domestic partnership, with over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former partners of the partnership post-transaction. The term 'corporate expatriation transaction' involves a foreign acquiring corporation obtaining properties of a domestic partnership, with over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock held by former partners of the partnership post-transaction. Special rules apply to treat a series of related transactions as one transaction. Special rules apply to treat a series of related transactions as one transaction, and stock held by members of the acquiring corporation's affiliated group is not considered in ownership determination. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' refers to a corporation that would be considered foreign if not for certain conditions. 'Expanded affiliated group' is defined as an affiliated group. The term 'expanded affiliated group' refers to an affiliated group without considering certain conditions. The Secretary of the Treasury will adjust corporate tax rates to offset any revenue changes resulting from the amendment. The amendment made by subsection (a) may result in a net decrease in revenues for a taxable year equal to the net increase in revenue for that year. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine tax rates based on estimates and make adjustments for succeeding years if prior estimates were off. Effective dates for the amendment are specified in the section. The amendment made by this section applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions completed on or before that date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003.
